Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 04:04AM mom3band1g wrote: OH thank you!  I was just talking to my ps's PA about fat grafting.  Right now  I look like someone split  cantaloup and attached each side to my chest.  Not pretty.  The PA was saying that fat grafting could help soften the look.  My rads side is tight as a drum.....off to look at the links you posted. thanks!
Posts.Title: Fat Graft Transfer and the Radiated Breast whippetmom dancetrancer

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2010 03:56AM mom3band1g wrote: I did too.  Failed lumpetomy and then mast.  I had multifocal areas of less than 1mm margins on the chest wall side and a 1mm margin skin side.  I had TE's in place during rads as well.  I just finished rads beginning of July.  I did really well with it but it was a pain going everyday.
Posts.Title: Just curious - who had a mx and still had to have rads? Houndmommy weety

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2010 04:14AM mom3band1g wrote: For me.....if I could have I would have jumped at the chance to keep my breasts.  I am 7 months out from my mast and will have my exchange surgery next month (put on hold due to rads) and emotionally it has been very hard.  I know for some women it's not as difficult but for me it's been truly hard.  If it wasn't medically necessary I'd keep them.  I was 39 at diagnosis and surgery and have many many years left with these fake boobs.  I miss my real ones every stinking day. This is a very hard decision and truly a personal choice.  Wishing you the best.

Posts.Title: ridding your body of GA mom3band1g badger

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 05:23PM mom3band1g wrote: Another one to say 'yes' it can all be DCIS!  I had 6.5c+cm, literally went from skin to chest wall and all DCIS!  Wishing the best for you.  You are in the hardest place right now.  Just know it does get easier (as hard as that is to believe).
Posts.Title: Dr.'s words: "I am more concerned than not concerned" ebarb mom3band1g

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 05:29AM mom3band1g wrote: Just saw this...I'm in Atlanta too!  My DCIS was found because I found a lump.  I guess it's unusual for DCIS to present with a palpable lump but it does happen.  In all of my diagnostic testing the lump only showed on MRI.  Everone could feel it but we just couldn't 'see' it until I had the MRI.  I had a lumpectomy with zero clear margins.  None of the rest showed on any testing.  Ended up going from nipple to chest wall.  DCIS is tricky stuff.  I think my bs said that basically, yes, the cells have filled the duct and pushed out without actually breaking out.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: DCIS question hope2011 mom3band1g

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2010 10:38AM mom3band1g wrote: So, I saw this header under "active topics" and had to click.  Forgive me if I am intruding but I did want to add my 2 cents.  I am one of those DCIS women.  I found my lump last December when I was 39.  I have felt very guilty for feeling scared, mad, etc because I was so 'lucky' to be pre-invasive.  My own Mother told me I didn't really even have cancer.  I had a lumpectomy with failed margins.  I had to have a mastectomy and then 6 weeks of radiation.  I still struggle with feeling like I didn't really have a right to be scared.  The truth is though, I did have a loss.  I did lose my breasts like many other women and I did lose 6 weeks to radiation.  I wouldn't ever compare myself to those with a higher stage than I.  I know my risk for recurrence is very low and for this I should feel thankful.  I cannot help but be angry that I lost my breasts.  I think I am more upset by the mast than anything else!  I guess I have learned that we can never truly know what is going on with someone else.  People all cope differently and just because someone looks one way on the outside doesn't really mean anything.  I am almost embaressed to tell people what I have been through.  I never tell anyone I had DCIS.  We all have our struggles and all we can do is try and help each other. Hope I haven't stepped on toes or offended anyone.
Posts.Title: Taboo subject mollynminnie mom3band1g

Posts.Content: May 23, 2011 02:00PM mom3band1g wrote: recon changes the whole thing as far as recovery.  I think those who don't do recon recover much quicker.  I found it very difficult, i was 39 and my 4 kids are on the young side.  I had a hard time physically and emotionally recovering.  I was never OK with the mast but you seem to have a good attitude about it so you may do just fine.  don't hesitate to ask for PT after surgery. Good luck.
Posts.Title: High Grade DCIS - Full Mastectomy Lifeafter Lifeafter

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 03:28AM mom3band1g wrote: Suzie - So good to hear your outcome!  I cannot wait to have my exchange!  Love the 'fluff and look their best" comment...made me laugh!  Picturing a 'fluffy' breast, ha ha.
Posts.Title: These %$@* TEs! joyko mawhinney

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2010 10:56AM mom3band1g wrote: Joyko - Hi!  I have the opposite problem...my cancer side 'slipped' and is now much lower than the other side.  I told my ps I dreamt my TE slid down into my belly.  He did laugh...he's very sweet.  He assures me it can be fixed when I have my exchange....you know, in November.  This summer should be fun.  I can see it now "hey, Mom...what's that in your bathing suit?"  "oh, just my boob".  It's so low that a cami with a shelf bra is uncomfortable because the elastic rides up.  Ugh.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 11:30AM mom3band1g wrote: my lump didn't show up on mammo or ultrasound!  I think it happens more often than we realize.
Posts.Title: How to handle pulpable lumps that don't show up on mammograms dense SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2010 07:31AM mom3band1g wrote: I was/am 39.  I found the lump  myself.  Dr sent me for my first mammo and ultrasound.  Lump didn't show up on either and they told me it must be nothing.  My Dr said 'no' and had me see a breast specialist.  Thank goodness for my awesome Dr.  Lump was cancer.  Had unsucc lumpectomy and am now scheduled for mast next week.  Reading how some women have had a mast and years later end up with mets scares the you-know-what out of me.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 08:55PM mom3band1g wrote: My radiologist from my mammo told me my lump was nothing because she couldn't get it to show up.  I was told to come back in 6 months....if I wanted.  Seriously!  No referal to a bs, no mention of dense breasts, nothing.  I was very angry about that but am thankful my gp sent me on to a bs.   I, too, never imagined that there was even such thing as false negative (especially with a palpable lump).
Posts.Title: How to handle pulpable lumps that don't show up on mammograms dense SarahsMom

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 07:22AM mom3band1g wrote: Just found this thread....haven't read all 22 pages though!  I finally found a PT who specializes in dealing with women who have had a mast....she had one herself.  I found that most of my pain was stuck muscle fascia and a lot of cording.  My muscles keep wanting to 'cord' back up.  It hurts a lot.  The massage she does to release the cording us a pain like no other but it works.  If I could afford it I would see someone who practices myo-fascia release.  I know that would help a lot.  I kind of feel like at this point my pain is tolerable and hope with time it goes away.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrome (PMPS) Deeds Lezza13

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2010 06:25AM mom3band1g wrote: I chose lumpectomy and was fine with that choice.  It didn't work out for me and I am now facing a mastectomy, but if they could have gotten clean margins with the lump I would have been very happy.  I would gladly do rads if it meant I could keep my breast.  I know it is an intensly personal decision and I hope it works out for the best for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2010 12:31PM mom3band1g wrote: Not to scare but to inform.  I had a palpable lump that did not show on mammo or ultrasound.  I had an excellent bs who decided to biopsy it.  It was cancer.  I was 39, so a little older than you, but still young!  I would seek the opinion of a breast surgeon.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: May 29, 2010 07:26AM mom3band1g wrote: Anyone know what happens if you have a mast with rads and it comes back?
Posts.Title: is it possible to go through rads more than once? tovahsmom sweatyspice

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2010 08:10AM mom3band1g wrote: Yes.  I too  had a lump right by my nipple.  My lump was very palpable but did not show up on mammo or ultrasound.  The mammo center told me it was nothing and not to worry.  Thankfully my fam Dr was not happy with this and referred me on to a breast surgeon. The bs did a biopsy and the rest is in my sig.  Please tell your daughter to find a good breast surgeon.  I was only 39. Even if it turns out to be 'nothing' it's better to know than guess.  Good luck. *My 1cm lump did show on MRI but the other 6.5cm did not show up on any testing.
Posts.Title: Worried About Daughter amlg1 amlg1

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 11:06AM mom3band1g wrote: I don't have time to read all your responses but it sounds like yeast to me.  A yeast infection is very itchy and painful!  If it's yeast you need to clear it up before your baby comes!! Nursing with a yeasty breast is very painful.
Posts.Title: too young??? chelsey_2009 CheriD

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2011 05:29AM mom3band1g wrote: So nice to find this thread.  I miss my breasts every stinking day.  I hate these fake things.  They are cold and too big.  I cannot bring myself to every be with my dh without a camisole on.  I just can't do it.  I don't think he minds.  He's just happy to have some lovin!  I don't feel like much of a woman anymore either.  I had no idea my breasts were so tightly tied to how I felt about myself as a sexual being.  They were very small but mine and they were a wonderful part of our sex life.  I mourned the loss of my breasts and am still mourning the loss of that part of our sex life.  I was 39 when I had my mast and just finished nursing my last babe.  I never really got them back after so many years of being pregnant and nursing.  I feel cheated.  I know I should just be grateful but I'm still sad.
Posts.Title: I miss my breasts! topless karen1956

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 01:13PM mom3band1g wrote: mahometomom62 - I cannot wear a bra because of a similiar issue.  It causes a bruisy/sore area only on my radiated side, just under my foob.  I believe (for me) it's cording issues.  I have several of these sore spots all around my stupid foob.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrome (PMPS) Deeds Lezza13

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2010 09:57AM mom3band1g wrote: I just had a bi-lat mast 3-25.  I had to have the right side but I chose the left side.  For me, this was an agonizing decision.  I really struggled.  It is a very hard sugery.  I was diagnosed at 39 and turned 40 shortly after my surgery.  I am numb from my shoulder blades to my sternum.  I may regain some sensation......not a lot.  Losing sensation in my breasts was/is a big deal.  I really enjoyed that!  It is such a personal decision and different for everyone. I think understanding exactly what is involved and the total out-come is very important.  I would talk to a plastic surgeon or 2 (or 3!) and see if you can talk to some women who have had a single and a double and see what they say.  My ps had a nurse who had had a double and she was kind enough to show me her results and even touch them (odd sounding but so helpful!).  It helped.  This is truly a tough decision and I wish you the best.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and I need advice! 1WonderWoman goodvibesonly

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2011 05:02PM mom3band1g wrote: amsk- I actually had no intention of going larger!  I was very adament with my ps that I was always happy with my small breast size (AA at best).  He kept saying he wasn't going to make me big and he used 325 implants.  He claims he's never used an implant that small.  I know I look very proportionate but I am not used to having these lumps on my chest.  It was just not something I ever wanted.  I am trying to get used to them as we cannot afford another surgery.  It sucks.  You are right about our situation not being as bad as someone who has lost their legs, arms. etc and I do try to remind myself of that.  I guess we need to let ourselves mourn and then try to let it go and move on.  Easier said than done!
Posts.Title: I miss my breasts! topless karen1956

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2010 04:56AM mom3band1g wrote: me, for bad margins.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 06:48AM mom3band1g wrote: I think you got excellent care and seeing a breast surgeon is absolutely to right 'next step'.  Just because the lump doesn't show up on mammo or ultrasound doesn't mean it's not something to worry about.  As my breast surgeon said 'we'll all sleep better when we know what it is'.  Hoping it is nothing for you to worry about but glad you are going through the steps.  Best of luck.
